But as the days went by, I began to notice the little things – the way he'd glance at his phone during dinner, the way he'd smile when talking to her on the phone.

My social calendar dwindled, and I stopped attending events, afraid of running into Jamie or Sophia.

My apartment became a reflection of my mood – dark colors, muted lighting, and a perpetual sense of melancholy. I stopped taking care of myself, letting my hair grow longer and my skin sallow. I'd stare blankly at my computer screen, unable to focus on any design project. My mind would wander back to Jamie and Sophia, replaying every conversation, every glance, every whispered promise.

Some nights, I'd lie awake, listening to the sound of Jamie's voice on his phone, whispering sweet nothings to Sophia. I'd imagine them together, laughing and loving, while I lay alone in my bed, feeling like a ghost haunting the edges of their world. Those moments were the worst – the ache in my chest, the sting of tears, the crushing weight of loneliness.

Now, as I sit here in the darkness, I realize that I've lost myself in this void. I've lost touch with the person I used to be – the person who laughed, who loved, who lived. All I can see now is Jamie, and the emptiness that surrounds him. And I know that if I don't find a way to break free from this prison, I'll never love again.
